Note.Content: In {S:04100801100026} (see {D:84.3}) and {S:04001600100022} (see {D:84.4}) there is a clear overlap of reference between ἀπό[c] and ἐκ[a].

No doubt the meanings in this series differ somewhat, but it is not possible on the basis of the contexts now available to determine precisely what designative or associative features of meaning may be involved.

The difference in meaning between the set κατά[g], ἐπί[s], ἐν[s], ἐκ[k], and καθώς[d] and the set πότε, ποτέ[b], ὁπότε, ὅτε[a], and ὅταν[b] ({D:67.30}) is largely a matter of class meanings, but there may be certain subtle rhetorical differences as well.

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: extension from an area or space, usually with the implication of removal out of a delimited area
a marker of cause or reason, with focus upon the source{N:002}
a marker of means as constituting a source
LEXSense.Comments: Some scholars have interpreted ἐκ in {S:04201600900016} as ἐκ[g] ‘apart from’ (see {D:89.121}). This requires the reading of ἐκλίπητε (found in a few late manuscripts) for ἐκλίπω in {S:04201600900016}b.

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: (with the genitive) a marker of instrument, with the added implication of result
a marker of manner, often with the implication of source
(with the genitive) a marker of the source of an activity or state, with the implication of something proceeding from or out of the source
a marker of dissociation in the sense of being independent from someone or something
LEXSense.Comments: In {S:04600901900008} it may be valuable to relate the first part of the verse to what immediately follows, for example, ‘for I am not a slave of anyone, but I make myself a slave to everyone’ or ‘though I am not anyone’s slave, I serve everyone.’

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: a marker of the source from which someone or something is physically or psychologically derived
a marker of a part of a whole, whether consisting of countables or of mass
a marker of the aspect of cessation

LEXSubDomains.LEXSubDomain: A Point of Time with Reference to Other Points of Time: Before, Long Ago, Now, At the Same Time, When, About, After

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: a marker of a point of time which is simultaneous to or overlaps with another point of time{N:003}

LEXSubDomains.LEXSubDomain: Duration of Time with Reference to Some Point of Time: Until, Delay, Still, From

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: a marker of the extent of time from a point in the past
a marker of price
a marker of the substance of which something consists or out of which it is made

LEXSubDomains.LEXSubDomain: High Status or Rank [including persons of high status]

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: (an idiom, literally: to sit on the right side of) to be in a position of high status

Glosses.Gloss: to sit on the right side of

LEXSense.Comments: Compare the use of ἀριστερός in {D:87.35} and see the discussion of {S:04101003700020} there. For another interpretation of {L:δεξιός<SDBG:δεξιός:000000>} in {S:04101003700020}, see {D:82.8}.

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: (an idiom, literally: from a part) the state of being part of something
(an idiom, literally: from measure) a scalar point marking considerable limitation in the extent of some activity
LEXSense.Comments: In a number of languages this expression in {S:04300303400026} may be appropriately rendered as ‘he doesn’t hold back at all when he gives the Spirit’ or ‘he gives the Spirit in an abundant way.’

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: (an idiom, literally: from excess) an extremely high point on a scale of extent and implying excess
LEXSense.Comments: In {S:04100605100028} both {L:λίαν<SDBG:λίαν:000000>} ({D:78.1}) and ἐκ περισσοῦ are expressions of degree and they reinforce one another.

LEXSubDomains.LEXSubDomain: Duration of Time with Reference to Some Point of Time: Until, Delay, Still, From

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: an exceedingly long period of time from an assumed beginning up to the present
(an idiomatic frame, literally: from … to …) a degree of totality emphasizing exclusiveness or the elimination of other possibilities

LEXSubDomains.LEXSubDomain: High Status or Rank [including persons of high status]

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: (an idiom, literally: to sit on the left side of) to be in a position of high status, but less than in the case of the right side (compare {D:87.34})

Glosses.Gloss: to be given somewhat less high status
to sit on the left side of

LEXSense.Comments: Compare the use of δεξιός in {D:87.34}.|In a number of languages the equivalent of this entire expression in {S:04101003700028} would be ‘in order that one of us may be number one and the other may be number two in your kingdom’ or ‘in order that one of us may be your first officer and the other your second officer in your kingdom.’ For another interpretation of {L:ἀριστερός<SDBG:ἀριστερός:000000>} in {S:04101003700028}, see {D:82.7}.

LEXSubDomains.LEXSubDomain: Opposite, Over Against, Across From, Offshore From

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: a position over against an object or other position
pertaining to being hostile toward
